positive.review:
One of the best Idle Games in my opinion. It might be a bit boring at the very start or later in-game when you unlock most of stuff, since you are slowly earning your way for better and faster automated upgrades. There are also Skins and Hats so you can customize your ninja the way you like it. If you are thinking about 100% achievements, well it takes a lot of time and patience, so no need to hurry, might as well put it in back running sometimes. 
If you like Idle Games it wont hurt to give it a try, maybe you like it, maybe not, you never know. Not everyone has the same taste.

683 heures de jeu au compteur

   Un incontournable pour les amateurs d'idle games

   Après plus de 680 heures de jeu, je peux affirmer sans hésitation que Tap Ninja est un excellent représentant du genre idle game, et probablement l'un des meilleurs actuellement disponibles.

   Progression équilibrée et respectueuse du joueur

   La courbe de progression est remarquablement bien calibrée. Le jeu parvient à maintenir un rythme satisfaisant sans tomber dans les pièges habituels du genre : pas de murs de progression
   insurmontables, pas de système agressif vous poussant vers les microtransactions. Chaque session apporte un sentiment tangible d'avancement, ce qui est essentiel pour maintenir l'engagement sur le long
   terme.

   Contenu saisonnier et Conquest : une diversité bienvenue

   Le contenu saisonnier renouvelle régulièrement l'expérience et offre des objectifs à court terme motivants. Le mode Conquest mérite une mention particulière : il apporte une vraie diversité gameplay et
   brise la monotonie des idle games. Cette variété dans les mécaniques de jeu contribue grandement à la longévité du titre.

   Verdict

   Si vous êtes amateur d'idle games, Tap Ninja est un must-have. Le jeu respecte votre temps, offre une progression gratifiante et propose suffisamment de contenu varié pour justifier des centaines
   d'heures de jeu. Un titre que je recommande sans réserve à tous les fans du genre.

I've seen a few negative comments about the game being predatory is ridiculous.  I paid the $5 or so, several years ago to get permanent VIP and haven't spent anything since.  Don't spend like a crazy person and instead plan coin spending to coincide with weekly events so that you either stay even or gain a little.  The new seasons is great, it's really bumped up free currency and gives more to do.  I think it still needs some balancing, but it's a step in the right direction!  Keep up the good work.

Becoming a Ninja Master in this game is basically a combo of doing taxes and karate. You slash enemies with perfect timing, collect coins like a squirrel on caffeine, and somehow run a whole village while also befriending a menagerie of pets. There are riddles, achievements, and weekly challenges to make sure you never relax. Honestly, I didn’t know I needed my cat to help me conquer enemy provinces, but here we are. 10/10, I feel simultaneously overpowered and slightly judged by my virtual dojo.

So I've saw some negative reviews, saying the game is heavily pay to win, but in my opinion, it's one of the best games ever! Those who are negative are the ones who are impatient, but I'm not. I love all styles of idle games like this one and I would highly recommend it to ANYONE who loves idle games. You can make progress by starting as a beginner, slowly advancing to make great profits and to be a powerful player! Long live Tap Ninja! 10/10

[quote][b][url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microtransaction]Warning: Microtransaction infested mobile app![/url][/b]

This game is infested with a toxic mobile app style cash shop.  You will be prompted to and expected to give money to the developers through this cash shop to buy in-game goods so you can play the game.[/quote]

"Tap Ninja - Idle game" is one of thousands of nasty mobile apps infesting the "free" section of Steam, but it's not really free.

This is a disgustingly monetized non-game, it's just an incrementer where you watch your "numbers"/score go up, with a bit of pixelcrap window dressing to make this mobile app almost appear to be a real game, but it's not.  You don't play it.  

But what you can do is pay an eye watering NINETY FOUR UNITED STATES DOLLARS, more than AAA pricing, on disgusting in-game currency bundles.  More on this disgusting monetization later.

There's only a superficial game here.   The game visuals and the game itself are incredibly shallow... think of them as the too-bright, colourful, thin plastic cabinet dress theme on a poker machine at the casino. That's basically what this is.  So really, the mobile app "game" is just a veneer, a thin skin wrapped around a nasty, predatory mobile app cash shop.

Putting that toxic mobile app monetisation aside... this is a mobile app.  I didn't spend thousands on a gaming PC so I could pretend it's an iPhone, and I don't think you did either... this kind of mobile app has no place in your Steam library.

On the important matter of pricing and value for gamers, there's a lot going on here with monetisation, so this really shouldn't be considered a truly free product because of that.

You're expected to pay up $94 USD to unlock content through DLC purchases.  The game should not be considered completely unlocked until you empty your wallet for the developer.  This is misleading and predatory pricing on a product falsely marketed as "free".

That's before the toxic cash shop... this truly is cancer.

Bearing in mind that free games don't add +1 to your game collector count, should you bother adding this to your library and downloading it?  What's the verdict?

Nope.  There's no up front cost here, but I still feel like I got ripped off, and I didn't even spend any money.  That's how bad this is.

There's not much to do at the start. The mid-game is more interesting with a few choices to make along the way, but your ability to influence the overall strategy is minimal. And the endgame is just 100% grind with the game artificially slowed to a crawl to entice in-game purchases.

There's plenty of better idle games out there, give this one a miss.

I'm pretty annoyed that you get WAY less ascension points when you don't have the game physically running vs offline. This basically forces you to AFK with it open which drains resources and is annoying. This game is also a tremendous grind and has very little active play other than clicking a dot on your screen about every minute. There's very little strategic decision making. This is the kind of game you either stop playing or play for a year and log in for a few minutes each day.

The new seasonal event update is complete garbage. This game is way too simple to be asking for as much money as they want just to progress. As time has went on the game continues to get more and more pay to participate, I would say pay to win but your not going to win. The game isn't an idle game anymore, it's a throw your wallet at it game, except even if you did spend money you still won't progress. This was a decent idle game now it's just trash that I shouldn't have played at all.
It gets boring quickly. It doesn't offer anything exciting or new.

I was a bit torn on this but the longer I played the more it shifted to negative.

I think the first few hours are all right, but there are some real issues here that grow as you progress into midgame.

1) The UI is clunky and feels out of proportion. If you want to have the upgrades screen open, there goes 15% of your screen (and messes with targeting orbs, see below). 
2) There are a lot of systems, several of which are monetized, though that's not even really the issue since you can bypass most of that. The issue is imo that a lot of those systems get dumped on you fast and furious, don't have great tooltips, and again, the UI is not awesome. That's a bad mix.
3) The first few hours are ok, but you pretty quickly move into mid-game and mid-game is like 95% idle, which would be fine except that the 'orb events' are not idle.  This would also be fine except each orb event is some number of min apart (3-8) and worth anywhere from several minutes of idle farming to seemingly several hours.

So the game is largely idle, but has events that are easy to miss and if you miss them it feels bad.  And that's before we get into the issues with the ninja minigame progression and the Fortress progression. Just the main loop feels...bad.

To a point I get what they're going for - largely idle but with some incentive for intermittent active play, and for some people maybe it's great but for me it feels unbalanced - everything but the orbs feels like a waste of time to me.
